results.description: Smash Cops is a series of top-down mobile games from Hutch Games casting the player as a member of an elite police force or a fleeing bandit in a series of hi-octane televised chases.
results.name: Smash Cops

results.description:
Overview

The first game in the Bravely Default series, Bravely Default: Flying Fairy, was originally going to be a 3DS sequel to Final Fantasy: 4 Heroes of Light. However, as development progressed and the game evolved into something quite different from a Final Fantasy title, the developers decided to abandon the ties to Final Fantasy in favor of a new franchise.

Flying Fairy was followed in Japan by a mobile title, Bravely Default: Praying Brage, as well as an upgraded version of Flying Fairy entitled Bravely Default: For the Sequel. For the Sequel is the edition of the game that was localized for release in western territories under the title Bravely Default.

On December 4, 2013, Square Enix announced a proper sequel to Flying Fairy entitled Bravely Second.

On December 12, 2019, Square Enix announced Bravely Default II.
results.name: Bravely Default

results.description: Two games were made in the series, some notable features of the games were the upgradeable units with several stats, the power distribution system where all structures had to be connected by power lines and the option to play the game in real-time mode or as a turn based strategy game.
results.name: M.A.X. - Mechanized Assault & Exploration

results.description:
Overview

The Trails franchise, known as "Kiseki" in Japan, is a sub-series of Falcom's long running Legend of Heroes RPG franchise, which in turn began as an entry in the Dragon Slayer family of games. All of the Trails titles take place in the same world and are all interconnected in one form or another but the franchise is also segmented into several story arcs that are directly connected, usually focusing on one region and one group of characters. Each arc contains one continuous storyline but the characters from each arc sometimes make appearances in future games and the events of each arc have an impact on the overall plot of the franchise, making the whole series one giant ongoing story.

Story Arcs

Liberl Arc

This arc follows the adventures of two adopted siblings, Estelle and Joshua Bright, on their quest to become fully-fledged Bracers as they travel through the kingdom of Liberl. Trails in the Sky the 3rd serves as an epilogue to the Liberl Arc and stars Kevin Graham and Ries Argent, a priest and squire from the Septian Church, who are trapped in alternate dimension known as the Phantasma.

  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky (2004)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky SC (2006)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky the 3rd (2007)

Crossbell Arc

An arc that takes place in the city-state of Crossbell where Lloyd Bannings, a fresh-faced detective, is assigned to a new unit known as the "Special Support Section" designed to help improve the police's relationship with the citizens.

  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails from Zero (2010)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails to Azure (2011)

Erebonia Arc

Set in the Erebonian Empire, this arc stars a military student named Rean Schwarzer that is enrolled in a special class known as "Class VII" which includes students from both the ruling nobility and commoners. Trails into Reverie serves as a transitional entry in the series where the story swaps between three different protagonists including Rean, Lloyd, and a mysterious figure only known as "C."

  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel (2013)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel II (2014)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel III (2017)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel IV (2018)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails into Reverie (2020)

Calvard Arc

These games observe the shady dealings of Van Arkride, a "Spriggan" that takes on odd-jobs in The Republic of Calvard that can't be handled by more respectable organizations.

  • The Legend of Heroes: Kuro no Kiseki (2021)
  • The Legend of Heroes: Kuro no Kiseki II - Crimson Sin (2022)

Spin-offs

  • Ys vs. Sora no Kiseki: Alternative Saga (2010) - Arena fighting game that features characters from both the Trails and Ys franchises.
  • The Legend of Nayuta: Boundless Trails (2012) - Action RPG that takes place in the same universe as the Trails series.
  • The Legend of Heroes: Akatsuki no Kiseki (2016) - Online RPG set in the world of Trails.
results.name: Trails

results.description:
Overview

Sengoku Hime is SystemSoft Alpha's series of strategy games featuring historical Japanese warriors reimagined as cute anime girls. Not to be confused with Sangoku Hime, SystemSoft Alpha's series of strategy games featuring historical Chinese warriors reimagined as cute anime girls.
results.name: Sengoku Hime

results.description:
Overview

Theatrhythm is a series of rhythm games based on touch screen gameplay mechanics. The original game, released on the 3DS and later ported to mobile devices, focused primarily on the first thirteen titles in the main Final Fantasy series, with a select few DLC songs taken from other sources. The sequel, Curtain Call, includes more music from not only the core franchise, but a variety of spin-off titles, as well.
results.name: Theatrhythm

results.description:
Overview

Hat Trick Hero and Hat Trick Hero 2 are a couple of Taito soccer games that were released on the Super Famicom. The first game was localized in the US, where it is known as Super Soccer Champ, and in Europe, where it is known as Euro Football Champ.

The sequel is a Japan-exclusive game. A planned localization of the game, which would've been named Super Soccer Champ 2, was cancelled during development.
results.name: Hat Trick Hero

results.description:
Overview

Super Granny is a series of casual action/puzzle games that are very similar to the Lode Runner series. The series stars Super Granny.
results.name: Super Granny

results.description:
Overview

Zan is a Sengoku era strategy sim series from Wolf Team in which the player controls one of many daimyo attempting to hold onto their own territory while conquering those belonging to others. Occasionally, the focus of the game switches from fighting fellow daimyos to repelling demonic armies from the underworld.

Games in Series

GameSystemDate
Zan: Kagerou no TokiSharp X68000Dec '89
Zan: Yasha EnbukyokuPC-88, Mega DriveSept '90 (PC-88), March '91 (MD)
Zan GearGame GearOct '90
Zan 2: Kagerou no JidaiPC-98Sept '91
Zan: Youen no JidaiTG-CDDec '91
Zan II: SpiritsSNESMarch '92
Zan 2: Towns SpecialFM TownsApril '92
Zan 3: Tenun Ware ni AriPC-98Dec '93
Zan III: SpiritsSNESMarch '94
Zan 3: Towns SpecialFM TownsMarch '94

There were also numerous Scenario Collection expansion packs for the computer versions of the above. Shortly after the last two games in the series, Wolf Team began focusing on what would eventually be Tales of Phantasia and the series for which they are best known.
results.name: Zan

results.description:
The first games in the series were Midnight Landing (1986) and Top Landing (1988). These were some of the first flight simulators to use 3D polygon graphics, and ran on the Taito Air System arcade board.

The Landing series went on to see the release of two more games: Landing Gear in 1996 and Landing High Japan in 1998.
results.name: Landing

results.description:
Industrial Domination

This is a game series made by SeaPandas Studios where you get to create and manage your own company during the industrial age. You can build factories, establish large transportation/communication networks or just buy all the land around the world to crush your competitors.
results.name: Industrial Domination

results.description:
Overview

Koushien is a series of high school baseball sims. The first two games were developed by Affect and published by K Amusement Leasing, but all subsequent games have been developed and published by Magical Company.
results.name: Koushien

results.description:
Overview

Yokoyama Mitsuteru Sangokushi, named for renowned manga artist Yokoyama Mitsuteru, is a Bandai published (via subsidiary Angel) and TOSE developed series of games that are based on the anime of the same name, which in turn are based on Mitsuteru's manga, which is based on the Chinese novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms (Sangokushi is its Japanese name). This gives the series the rare distinction of being video games based on a cartoon based on a comic based on literature.

The first two games in the series - Yokoyama Mitsuteru Sangokushi and Yokoyama Mitsuteru Sangokushi II - are war sims in the vein of Koei's Romance of the Three Kingdoms. The third, Yokoyama Mitsuteru Sangokushi Bangi, is a less complex board game variant on the same conflict.
results.name: Yokoyama Mitsuteru Sangokushi

results.description:
Overview

The F1 Circus games are a series of F1 racing games that mostly use a top-down perspective and prioritizes realism and simulation elements. The player's vehicle gets damaged and worn down as the race proceeds and the player can incur infractions for driving recklessly or incorrectly.

The Super Famicom entries, which have a different developer, all have the prefix "Super" in their titles.
results.name: F1 Circus

results.description:
Overview

Ultra Baseball, or Baseball Simulator 1.000, is a series of baseball sims from Culture Brain. Most are defined by their inclusion of superhuman abilities for the athletes, though these are usually restricted to a special league.

The first two games in the series, Choujin Ultra Baseball and Super Ultra Baseball, are best known in the West as Baseball Simulator 1.000 and Super Baseball Simulator 1.000. The subsequent four games in the series were only released in Japan.

The six games include:

  1. Choujin Ultra Baseball (Baseball Simulator 1.000)
  2. Super Ultra Baseball (Super Baseball Simulator 1.000)
  3. Ultra Baseball Jitsumeiban*
  4. Super Ultra Baseball 2
  5. Ultra Baseball Jitsumeiban 2*
  6. Ultra Baseball Jitsumeiban 3*

(* = These games were all officially licensed by the Nippon Professional Baseball league.)
results.name: Baseball Simulator 1.000

results.description: Not to be confused with the space-sim franchise also called X.
results.name: X

results.description:
Most of the video game adaptions have been developed and published by PAN Vision.

They were usually intended to be played alongside with the TV show, which airs daily from the 1st to the 24th of December every year, and during the show a code or password would be shown that players could input into the game to access bonus content. Some of the shows were based on past franchises (or literature), or became franchises on their own, particularly the Mysteriet på Greveholm series.

Since 2005, most of the games have been browser based, rather than retail PC or console releases.
results.name: Julkalendern

results.description:
Overview

The My-Hime Project is a Japanese cross-media franchise created by animation house Sunrise, spawning multiple anime series, manga, video games and novels during the mid to late 2000s. Its two main entries are the anime series My-HiME and My-Otome.
results.name: My-Hime Project

results.description: The Rocksmith series aims to teach players how to play guitar and bass. Songs are played on any real guitar that has a 1/4-inch jack socket through a jack-to-USB cabled that are bundled with the game or can be ordered directly.
results.name: Rocksmith

results.description:
Overview

Sid Meier's Ace Patrol is a series of war themed strategy games.
results.name: Sid Meier's Ace Patrol

results.description: A series of horror-themed typing games, based on the House of the Dead light gun games.
results.name: The Typing of the Dead

results.description:
Kaiju Combat began life as an attempted crossover game between hundreds of different kaiju characters from various media. When the first Kickstarter failed to reach its goal, this model was retooled. The current plan is to release a free game featuring characters from Kaijuland, followed by a full game with original kaiju, and to release special editions on different licenses as they become available.

Confirmed as additional guest characters in a future game are Solomon and Red, characters from the popular online horror story "NES Godzilla Creepypasta", about a demonic cartridge of "Godzilla: Monster of Monsters".

Due to a bizarre trademark dispute with Wizards of the Coast in early 2013, the company was forced to change the brand to "Colossal Kaiju Combat", but cannot use that name to sell any of their products.
results.name: Colossal Kaiju Combat

results.description:
Overview

Cosmo Gang: The Video and Cosmo Gang: The Puzzle are two Arcade Namco games that feature comical characters in variants based on classic Arcade games. Cosmo Gang: The Video plays on Namco's earlier Arcade hit Galaga and Cosmo Gang: The Puzzle is a variant on Tetris or Puyo Puyo that would later be adapted into Pac-Attack.

Though both games saw Super Famicom ports, neither game would be released outside of Japan.
results.name: Cosmo Gang

results.description:
Overview

In 1986, Arsys Software debuted with the 3D role-playing shooter Wibarm. It is considered the first 3D Role-Playing Shooter (RPS), combining elements of run & gun shooters, top-down shoot 'em ups, and real-time action role-playing games. The game featured open-world exploration as well as 3D polygonal graphics inside buildings. This is more of a spiritual predecessor to the Star Cruiser series, laying the foundations for it, rather than a direct plot-related prequel.

In 1988, Arsys released the 3D first-person shooter role-playing game Star Cruiser, a fully 3D role-playing shooter that anticipated the first-person shooter genre, years before Wolfenstein 3D and Doom. In addition to the first-person shooter combat, Star Cruiser also featured open-world exploration with six degrees of freedom as well as visual novel cut-scenes. In 1989, they released an enhanced port of Star Cruiser, which took advantage of the X68000's powerful hardware to produce the most advanced 3D polygon graphics seen on a home system of the 80's. In 1990, Star Cruiser was eventually ported to Sega's Mega Drive (Genesis) console.

When Star Cruiser was released in 1988, Arsys Software only had two employees, which grew to a dozen employees by 1991, when development began on Star Cruiser 2, which was eventually released in December 1992 for the NEC PC-9821 and FM Towns computers.

Awards

Wibarm and Star Cruiser won the following awards from leading Japanese computer publications at the time:

WiBArM (1986)

  • Oh!MZ (Oh!X) - Game of the Year

Star Cruiser (1988)

  • POPCOM - Game of the Year
  • Oh!X - Game of the Year
results.name: Star Cruiser

results.description:
Overview

The Death Trap trilogy was more or less Squaresoft's answer to Enix's successful Yuji Horii Mysteries trilogy of adventure games, years before they created Final Fantasy as their answer to Yuji Horii's Dragon Quest.

The first game, The Death Trap (1984), was produced by Hironobu Sakaguchi and programmed by Hiromichi Tanaka. It follows a Cold War era, proto-Metal-Gear (and somewhat Rambo-like) storyline, revolving around special agent Benson.

The second game, Will: The Death Trap II (1985), had Sakaguchi returning as producer as well as writer, with the addition of Nobuo Uematsu composing his first soundtrack for this game. The plot adds science fiction elements, making it somewhat more like the Metal Gear series than its predecessor. The game was considered a technical breakthrough for its use of animated bitmap graphics (predating the GIF animated bitmap format by two years) to render real-time animated cutscenes, a technique that would later be used in many later video games.

For the third game, Alpha (1986), Hiromichi Tanaka returns, this time replacing Sakaguchi's role as writer and director, with Nobuo Uematsu returning as composer. It was more of a spiritual successor rather than a direct sequel, with the gameplay similar to the first two Death Trap games and improving on the real-time animated cutscene technique of Will, but with a very different storyline. The plot took the science fiction elements in a more cyberpunk direction, set on a starship centuries in the future and with a new female protagonist Chris.

Reception and Legacy

All three games were major hits in the Japanese computer game industry, with the first game in particular selling up to 500,000 copies, more than any other computer game released up until then. Will and Alpha also sold hundreds of thousands of copies. Squaresoft's success with the Death Trap trilogy in the Japanese computer game industry paved the way for their later mainstream success with the Final Fantasy series of role-playing games in the console game industry.
results.name: Death Trap

results.description:
Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 was originally intended to be that last installment of the Persona franchise, which is itself a spinoff from the larger Shin Megami Tensei family. However, critical acclaim and steady sales influenced Atlus to collaborate with Arc System Works Co., Ltd. to spinoff the series into a fighting game, Persona 4 the Ultimate in Mayonaka Arena (known as Persona 4: Arena in the West). The title notably shed the "Shin Megami Tensei" prefix, as would all future installments in the franchise, indicating that Persona and Shin Megami Tensei were to be treated as separate entities.

In 2011, to coincide with the timeline of the original game, Atlus commissioned AIC ASTA to adapt the story into a 25-episode anime. The series was well-received upon release. Parts of key episodes were edited into a feature film and released theatrically.

With the launch of the PlayStation Vita, Atlus remastered Persona 4 as Persona 4: the Golden, with updated visuals, several gameplay improvements, and additional story content. In addition to being the best-reviewed game on the platform, Golden sold over 1 million units, making it the best-selling Atlus JRPG until the release of Persona 5.

The major success of Golden prompted Atlus to spinoff the series further, beginning work on a sequel to the Ultimate - Persona: 4 the Ultimax Ultra Suplex Hold (localized as Persona 4: Arena Ultimax) - a first-person dungeon crawler for the Nintendo 3DS - Persona Q: Shadow of the Labyrinth - and a rhythm dancing game - Persona 4: Dancing All Night. With the exception of Persona Q, the events depicted in each spinoff are canonical. Each title takes place in the time between the True Ending of Persona 4 and the epilogue at the end of Golden, with Dancing All Night serving as the final adventure for the Investigation Team. The cast will be featured in Persona Q2: New Cinema Labyrinth.

Atlus also tapped A-1 Pictures to adapted the Golden in Persona 4: the Golden Animation. A manga series retelling the events of the original game, the Ultimate, and Persona Q were also released, as well as a light novel/manga extending the story of Naoto Shirogane, Persona x Detective Naoto.
results.name: Persona 4
